By GEORGE SKEGAS
The Hopkins fencers
successfully defended their MAC
crown in Philadelphia at the
conference tournament Saturday
by compiling an outstanding
56-16 record. Temple University,
the host team finished second
with a 40-32 bout record. The 16
point spread was the widest ever
achieved in the 22 history of the
MAC championships.
Team competiton saw the Blue
Jays completely dominate the
sabre competition with a fine
23-1 record good for first place.
In the two other. weapons,
Hopkins finished second by the
slimmest of margins. Both-in. the
foil and epee, the Blue Jays duos
missed first place by a single 5-4
bout.
Individually, five of the six
Homewood ,fencers entered in
the competition won medals. No
other school managed to win
more than one of the nine
individual medals available.
Co-captain John Roberts led

the Jays with a spectacular effort
in the sabre group. Compiling an
amazing 12-0 record,. Roberts
destroyed his opponents. With
his flawless win he became only
the third sabreman to go
undefeated in MAC
championship history. He also
d
the first Blue Jay to
stand unbeaten in a conference
tournament. Junior Bruce
Livingston was almost as strong,
finishing second in the sabree
with an 11-1 record. The only
blemish of his *day was another
5-4 bout.
In the epee competition,
sophomore Tom Slota did
especially well, finishing second
with a 9-3 mark. He lost the
match that would have given him
first place by a single touch.
Mark Davis followed close behind
with a third place finish on an
8-4 record.
The foil pool boasted the
strongest field of swordsmen in
the tournament, as was expected.
Co-captain Glenn Pantel and

sophomore Bob Baum finished
third and fourth in the pool for
the Blue Jays, just missing the
team title. Pantel earned a 9-3
record while Baum turned in a
7-5 card.
Coach Dick Oles was very
pleased with the team's
performance in the tournament.
Now he is hopeful the team will
continue this upcoming weekend,
when Hopkins will travel to
South Orange, New Jersey, for
the North Atlantic Conference
tournament at Seton Hall.
The Blue Jays will then host
the alumni on the following
weekend in a tuneup for the
NCAA Championship
tournament, which will be held
at Case-Western Reserve on the
final weekend in March.

four Blue Jays were named to the
All-Conference squad; Livingston
and Ron Kramer were selected
for the sabre division. Also
named were John Burdakin in
epee and Mike Brunner at foil.
